<section>

## Introduzione

## Why this project

<p style="font-size: 30px; text-align:left;">The project I've decided to implent has the purpose to analyze some hotels client's reviews.All of us have at least once reviewed, positively or negatively, a hotel because we were struck by certain peculiarities of the structure.</p>

<p style="font-size: 30px; text-align:left;">Above all, however, before booking any hotel each of us read all the reviews in detail to understand whether or not to book. But have you ever wondered what all reviews have in common?</p>

<p style="font-size: 30px; text-align:left;">I have, and I would like to solve this doubt.</p>


## The dataset

<p style="font-size: 25px; text-align:left;">
I found the daset I used on kaggle.com and is named "hotel_reviews.csv". The daset contains 512k reviews of some clients reguarding about 1500 luxury hotels all over Europe. The dataset is composed by 17 fields which are shown below
</p>

```{r}
reviews<-read.csv("Hotel_Reviews.csv")
hreviews<-data.frame(reviews)

```
<div style="font-size: 25px; text-align:left; font-family='Helvetica';">

  + _Hotel_Name_: identifica il nome dell'hotel 
  + _Hotel_Address_: specifica l'indirizzo dell'hotel (useremo solo il paese)
  + _Review_Date_: data della recensione 
  + _Reviewer_Nationality_: Nazionalit√† del cliente che ha recensito l'hotel
  + _Negative_Review_: recensione negativa 
  + _Positive_Review_: recensione positiva
  + _ReviewTotalNegativeWordCounts_: numero totale di parole negative usate
  + _ReviewTotalPositiveWordCounts_:  numero totale di parole postive usate
  + _Reviewer_Score_:punteggio assegnato dal cliente 
  + _TotalNumberof_Reviews_: Numero totale delle review dell'hotel 
  + _lat_:latitudine dell'hotel 
  + _long_: longitudine dell'hotel
  
</div>

## Question to answer

<div style="font-size: 25px; text-align:left;">

With a dataset so rich in information, many questions have arisen to understand the different relationships between reviews, these are the most important that I will deepen in the course of my project.

+ Which is the best luxury hotel in Europe?
+ Which is the worst luxury hotel?
+ Is there any correlation between the client's nationality and the rating assigned to the hotel?
+ What are the words customers use most frequently for negative and positive reviews?
+ What is the average number of words of a review (positive and negative)?

</div>

</section>

## Classifica globale

## Best
```{r}
 classifica1 <- arrange(hreviews3,-mean_sc)

  podio1<-classifica1%>%head(3)
  
  po1<-data.frame(podio1$Hotel_Name,podio1$mean_sc)

  ggplot(po1, aes(x=podio1$Hotel_Name, y=podio1$mean_sc)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", width=0.5, fill="light green") +
    xlab("Hotel Name")+
    ylab("Average Score")+
    coord_flip()+
    theme(legend.position="none")
```

## Spain Correlation 
 
```{r}
hotelSpagna2<-hreviews%>%
  select(Hotel_Name,Reviewer_Nationality,Reviewer_Score,lat,lng
)
hotelSpagna3<-hotelSpagna2%>% 
  filter((between(lat,41,41.5)))


prova<- filter(hotelSpagna3,Hotel_Name=="Sansi Diputacio")
ggplot(prova, aes(Reviewer_Score , Reviewer_Nationality)) + geom_point()

# linear model 
mod1 = lm(Reviewer_Score~Reviewer_Nationality, data = prova)

```

## 

```{r}

ggplot(prova,aes(Reviewer_Score , Reviewer_Nationality)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_abline(intercept = mod1$coefficients[1], 
              slope = mod1$coefficients[2], 
              color = "red")
```

## Analisi dettagliata 

## Positive Reviews


```{r}

text_df <- tibble(line = 1:515738, text = recensioni$Positive_Review)
rus_stopwords = data.frame(word = stopwords("ru"))


new_df <- text_df %>% unnest_tokens(word, text)

new_df1<-new_df %>%
  filter(!(word %in% stopwords("english")))

frequency_dataframe = new_df1 %>% count(word) %>% arrange(desc(n))

short_dataframe = head(frequency_dataframe, 25)
ggplot(short_dataframe, aes(x = word, y = n, fill = word),ylab="") +theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90))+ geom_col() +ylab("Count")
```

## Graphic Rappresentation

```{r}
wordcloud(words = frequency_dataframe$word, freq = frequency_dataframe$n, min.freq = 1,
          max.words=200, random.order=FALSE, rot.per=0.35, 
          colors=brewer.pal(8, "Dark2"))
```
